doc.title: Alibaba (Preview & Thoughts) / SJM (Poor 2Q) / Global Luxury (Thoughts & Discussions) / @10am Expert Call on China FD & QC Mkt
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/JPM APAC Consumer Internet Aug 29 -- Alibaba Preview SJM poor results Global Luxury Thoughts DiscussionsJPM APAC Consume_2025-08-29

passages.text: Mini Labubus went on sale last night on PopMart and was sold out within 1 min (I failed ...), confirming that the popularity continues. Overnight, a flurry of US retail co's reported a solid print but with guidance or positioning creating reason for the fade: 1) ULTA \((+3\%)\) post- mkt) strong beat + raise reads well for Asia cosmetics (LSD%/MSD% in Mass/Prestige respectively) though it warned of potential pullback by consumers; 2) DKS \((- 4.8\%)\) despite solid top- line, on high bar & 2H uncertainty on tariffs & promotional uncertainty; (3) DG \((+0.5\%)\) beat + raise but is well held; (4) BBWI \((- 7\%) / \mathrm{GAP}\) \((- 5\%)\) post mkt) called out big tariff impacts. Other standouts: DHER \((- 6\%)\) cuts outlook on FX but discussed "Asia clearly improving", ATAT \((+4.6\%)\) breaking out and Europe Luxury seeing another strong day (see below commentary). Today in Asia, the single most watched print will be Alibaba after- mkt today, so I've recapped views & thoughts post JD/Meituan below. Let me know if you'd like to join our expert call @10am HKT today. Elsewhere, SJM reported a 2Q miss (no read- thru to industry) and lastly, we hosted Laopu Gold for an NDR in China yesterday - momentum appears strong even post Mon's price hikes. Let me know if you'd like to chat! Gold Happy Friday! Best, Lisa

- Alibaba (9988 HK, OW) - Preview into results tonight = final one!! (Sales Commentary)- SJM Holdings (880 HK, Neutral) - Poor 2Q results, but does it really matter? We think not (Link)- Global Luxury - Recent thoughts & discussions (Sales Commentary)- Expert Call Today: @10am HKT - Competitive Landscape in China's Food Delivery and Quick Commerce Market (Register)

JPM Key Conference/Tours:  \* K-Pop, Beauty & Bio Tour in Seoul (Sept 8-10)  \* Global Beauty Conference in London (Sept 18)  \* Global Luxury & Brands Conference in Paris (Nov 12-13)  \* Global TMT Conference in HK (Nov 17-18)
Use the links below to jump straight to each section:
Detailed Highlights  Section Key Newsflow  Full Research Links  Save the Date: JPM Consumer & Internet EventsCatalyst Calendar (Full Version)  Detailed Highlights

- Preview/Thoughts (Reports after-mkt HKT/Briefing @19:30 here): The 3x numbers I will focus on for the June print itself would be 1) Group adj. EBITA (Cons Rmb 43bn, JPMc 38.3bn), 2) Cloud Revenue/EBITA (Cons: 32bn/3bn; JPMc: 32bn/2.6bn), 3) Capex (JPMc \(\sim 25\mathrm{bn}\) flat q/q). Given their re-segmentation (China E-Commerce, International Digital Commerce, Cloud Intelligence, Others), E-Commerce will now include Ele.me (Food Delivery) and Fliggy (OTA) as well so will be one harder to compare like-for-like. In the briefing, the main focus will be on Alibaba's tone around spending/competition around FD/QC and outlook around Cloud.

- Thoughts on investments: Post JD's bigger than expected losses in New Business (Rmb 15bn of which FD was \(\sim 14\mathrm{bn}\) vs 10bn exp) and Meituan( \(\sim \mathrm{Rmb}10\mathrm{bn}\) vs the expected less than 3bn), the read-through on investments for Alibaba is clearly negative. For reference, Alex Yao is assuming FD/QC spending of just under 6bn/17bn in June/Sept Q respectively (ie. Sept Q to be a bigger quarter in spending) - these numbers are pre-Meituan reporting. However, when thinking about the magnitude of spending impact, there's a few things to remember: a) Alibaba holds \(\sim 550\mathrm{bn}\) net cash; b) the \(\sim \mathrm{Rmb}200\mathrm{bn}\) annual profit they make from E-Commerce alone (Tmall/Taobao) or \(\sim 50\%\) of their total revenue; c) Local Consumer Services (includes Ele.me in previous segmentation) was \(6 - 7\%\) of group's total revenue and loss making last FY. In other words, Alibaba can cover their investments much better than that of Meituan (that has \(\sim 75\%\) of rev from core local commerce). Nevertheless, a much higher than expected spending will pressure the group's bottom-line so therefore will be a key watch number.

- Feedback: Some bulls point to the "set up being not as bad" for Alibaba given the market has largely de-risked on investments after JD/Meituan and some mention on points above re: larger financial base etc. And yesterday, we saw both Meituan and Alibaba at the top of the buy list from Southbound. That said, we've not seen much activity in putting on risk into tonight... Given the amount of work needed for re-modeling Meituan, it does not sound like investors have changed estimates around for Alibaba pre-print... so one that will be worked through likely over the weekend. Given the rare occasion of announcing on a Friday, many nervous on what's to come.

- Expert speaker today @10am HKT: Alex Yao and Andre Chang from JPM's internet team are hosting a Chief Consulting Officer, former Meituan project director for a call to discuss the Competitive landscape in China's Food Delivery and Quick Commerce Market. Register here. \*Calls are for Mifid high-touch and out-of-scope clients only\*
- Alex Yao Views: He's written his latest views on Aug 22 (here) and Aug 15 (here) post JD results.

- Summary: SJM's 2Q results came in significantly below expectations on very weak margins, dragged by poor VIP luck and higher than expected OPex. That said, DS's cut in forward EBITDA is merely \(-4\%\) as the downside is partially offset by better-than-expected industry demand momentum. We think the impact on the stock - beyond the obvious knee jerk reaction - may not be that significant, and should have limited read-across to its peers. He thus remains Neutral, keeping it at the bottom of the pecking order - while remaining bullish on the Macau Sector as a whole. Balance sheet also has shown no signs of improvement either. PT cut to HK\(2.80 from\)3, based on SOTP = 15% downside from here.

- No update on satellite transactions: Management said it is still in negotiations with 2 satellite casino owners (L'ar and Ponte 10 for a potential acquisition with no comment on pricing or timing (except that if the transaction were to happen, should finalize by year-end given regulations). Note that this transaction is in somewhat of a focus because if SJM does not acquire and tables get returned to the government, there is possibility for other operators to increase their table count (MGM and Galaxy from our tour appeared more keen to have these tables vs Wynn - Sales commentary only!)

- Global Luxury basket (See below chart: \(+6\%\) from Aug bottom) - What's driving the strength? (Sales View) - We've seen a bottoming in the European luxury sector and attribute 3x potential reasons: (1) Big performance gap vs China indices - The lux sector has not participated in the China rally (like it used to) and historically has had the "China Proxy" correlation. (2) Positioning - Has been out of favor the last year with Lux sold down on China / Earnings momentum concerns and used to fund themes/rotations in Europe ie, into A&D. Prime positioning suggests Lux positioning at 36%-ile. (3) Confidence on US Consumer - Swatch group hosted a call (here) and discussed US consumer remaining strong despite price hikes and general
macro volatility; credit card data has a strong; wealth effect from stock market & crypto.

- The Disconnect: The latest 1H25 resulted to suggest a pretty somber outlook - highly volatile, tourists no longer an easy growth driver, new prices hike not adding to growth, no cluster improved in Q2 (if anything Americans and Chinese inc. tourist slowed down sequentially). There is a surprise on "why the sudden optimism?" Chiara wrote in detail on the results here

- Near-term catalysts: (1) Back to office - Many of the European lux companies have been out for holidays in the month of August and will return early September. They'll often update investors on latest news/thoughts... (moved stocks last year); (2) Zegna (ZGN US) reports on Sept 5 and will likely give a trading update; (3) Pre-close calls - will mostly take place likely the week of 22nd Sept;

- Prada (1913 HK, OW): In the next few weeks, we will get a closing of the Versace acquisition. Given the expected earnings dilution (between HSD% and some say mid teens%), as these numbers get baked into consensus, this could become a clearing event. Fundamentally, Chiara remains bullish As Miu Miu continues to be strong outperformer and expects overall EBIT growth to be 8%/10% this year and next, trading at 13x P/E on '26 JPMV vs the rest of luxury at 22x. See latest report here
- Meet Chiara Battistini? She will be in Singapore on Wed, Oct 1 & in Hong Kong on Thurs/Fri Oct 2 & 3 in case you'd like to meet her.
